raw_text:
UK's National Gallery in the pink
 
 The National Gallery, home to some of the UK's greatest artworks, has seen a big jump in visitor numbers.
 
 Five million visitors made the London gallery - which houses treasures like Raphael's Madonna of the Pinks - the UK's most visited museum in 2004. It recorded a 13.8% rise in numbers and was the country's second most visited tourist attraction, behind Blackpool Pleasure Beach. Charles Saumarez Smith, the gallery's director, said he was "delighted". He said the number of visitors through the doors had boosted figures to pre-11 September 2001 levels. Mr Saumarez Smith added that the pedestrianisation of Trafalgar Square, where the gallery is located, and strong temporary collections throughout 2004 had led to the strong performance.
 
 "Our 2004 exhibition programme of El Greco, Russian Landscape in the Age of Tolstoy and Raphael: From Urbino to Rome was particularly strong and exceeded all targets," he said. "The exceptional quality of the paintings in our permanent collection is also huge draw for the public. "The expectations of today's visitors are higher than ever and we have kept pace with their demands." Mr Saumarez Smith said he was confident the gallery could maintain the attendance. "With important exhibitions of the work of Caravaggio, Stubbs and Rubens in place for 2005, I am confident that the gallery is set for another highly successful year," he added. The figures were prepared by the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva).
 
 It found that the figures had been boosted by an increase in Europeans travelling to the UK on budget airlines. Popular cultural tourist spots such as the Tate Modern and the Natural History Museum all recorded increases of more than 10% in visitor numbers compared with 2003. But for legal or confidentiality reasons some Alva members did not submit figures for 2004, including Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, Madame Tussauds and Alton Towers. Alva director Robin Broke said: "Visits from Western Europe were up by 10% and from North America by some 9% compared to 2003, while numbers from the rest of the world rose 20%. "European figures were helped by the rapid growth of low-cost flights to Britain from Europe, especially from new EU countries."
llama3.2:1b:
The National Gallery in London has seen a significant increase in visitor numbers. 

Five million visitors made it the UK's most visited museum in 2004, with a 13.8% rise from previous year.

The gallery's director reported that the strong 2004 exhibition program, including works by El Greco and Raphael, exceeded targets and is expected to continue this performance.
llama3.2:3b: The National Gallery in London had a 13.8% rise in visitor numbers in 2004, becoming the UK's most visited museum with five million visitors. The gallery's director attributed this success to strong temporary collections and the pedestrianization of Trafalgar Square. Visitor figures from Europe increased by 10%, while those from North America rose by 9%.
gemma2:2b: The National Gallery in London saw a 13.8% increase in visitors in 2004, becoming the UK's most visited museum. This was attributed to factors like pedestrianization of Trafalgar Square, strong temporary collections, and its permanent collection's high quality.  A positive trend is expected in 2005 with upcoming exhibitions featuring Caravaggio, Stubbs, and Rubens. Overall visitor numbers saw a boost across various museums due to increased European tourism fueled by low-cost flights from Europe and North America.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The National Gallery in London, UK had a big increase in visitors. In 2004 it collected 5 million people and was second most visited tourist attraction after Blackpool Beach. Visitors increased through the streets of London too. Charles Saumarez Smith said "delighted" to see more visitors this year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The National Gallery in London saw a significant rise in visitor numbers, with five million visitors making it the UK's most visited museum. The gallery recorded a 13.8% increase and was ranked second among tourist attractions after Blackpool Pleasure Beach. Charles Saumarez Smith praised the gallery for boosting figures to pre-9/11 levels due to increased pedestrianization of Trafalgar Square and strong temporary exhibitions throughout 2004, including El Greco, Russian Landscape in the Age of Tolstoy, and Raphael: From Urbino to Rome. The quality of permanent collections was also highlighted as a draw for visitors.
qwen2.5:3b: The National Gallery in London, home to artworks like Raphael's Madonna of the Pinks, saw a significant increase in visitors reaching five million in 2004, making it the UK’s most visited museum. This marked a 13.8% rise and placed it second behind Blackpool Pleasure Beach as a tourist attraction. Director Charles Saumarez Smith expressed delight at the numbers, attributing them to pedestrianization of Trafalgar Square, strong temporary exhibitions (El Greco, Russian Landscape in the Age of Tolstoy, Raphael: From Urbino to Rome), and exceptional paintings in the permanent collection. He also highlighted upcoming important exhibitions for 2005 including Caravaggio, Stubbs, and Rubens. The Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva) reported that visitor numbers increased by over 10% at other popular museums like Tate Modern and Natural History Museum compared to 2003. Alva indicated that the rise in visitors was mainly due to increased tourism from Europe on budget flights, especially those coming from new EU countries.

<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the National Gallery in the UK. Let me read through it again.

The text starts by talking about the National Gallery's visitor numbers. It mentions five million visitors in 2004, which is a big increase compared to 2001, and that made it second most visited museum in the country. Charles Saumarez Smith, director of the gallery, is very happy with the rise.

He talks about Trafalgar Square getting pedestrianized and temporary collections happening, contributing to strong performance. There's an exhibition program that exceeded targets.

Some key points: 2004 figures, main increase in European visitors, legal confidentiality issues affecting Alva members, and 2015-2023 growth in flights from new EU countries leading to higher visitor numbers.

I need to condense all this into a summary without any extra information. I'll make sure to include the key points like the visitor numbers, the increase percentages, the reasons behind it, the director's feelings, and the factors contributing to future growth.
</think>

The National Gallery in the UK experienced a significant jump in visitor numbers with 5 million visitors in 2004, up from 2001 levels. This made it the second most visited museum in the country. The director, Charles Saumarez Smith, praised the rise and highlighted reasons for success, including Trafalgar Square becoming pedestrianized and temporary collections, and an exhibition program that met targets.

European visitor numbers rose by over 10%, while some Alva members didn't submit data due to confidentiality. Low-cost flights from new EU countries contributed to rapid growth in 2015-2023, though future growth will be assessed by visitor trends.
tinyllama:1.1b: The National Gallery in London has seen a record-breaking increase in visitor numbers due to increased attendance from European tourists and popular cultural attractions such as Buckingham Palace, Windsof Castle, Madame Tuissauds, and Altons. The figures were boosted by a 13.8% rise in European visitors compared with 2003, while the figures for the rest of the world also rose 20%. According to the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva), the figure for Legal and Confidentiality purposes only was increased by Western Europeans from 8.9 million in 2003 to 10.5 million in 2004, with North America up by some 9%.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The National Gallery in London has seen a big increase in visitor numbers over the past year. According to the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva), approximately five million visitors made their way to the UK's most visited museum in 2004, which is the second highest recorded figure since pre-September 11, 2001. This significant growth can be attributed to several factors, including increased tourist interest from Europeans and improvements in ticket pricing for budget airlines. Overall, Alva members experienced a 13.8% rise in visitor numbers compared to 2003.

The strong performance can be attributed to the gallery's pedestrianisation of Trafalgar Square, a temporary collection and exceptional quality of artwork. The figures were boosted by budget airlines increasing European travel to the UK. Alva's director is confident that the gallery will maintain these high numbers with important exhibitions set for 20005. Other popular cultural attractions such as the Tate Modern and Natural History Museum also saw increases in visitor numbers compared to 200

Increased visitor numbers attributed to strong exhibition program, quality of permanent collection, and pedestrianization of Trafalgar Square.

The gallery director, Charles Saumarez Smith, expressed his delight at the results, stating that they had kept pace with the expectations of modern visitors. He also noted that upcoming exhibitions for the following year would contribute to continued success. The figures were prepared by the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva), which reported a 10% increase in visits from Western Europe and 9% from North America compared to 2003, with the rest of the world seeing an 20% rise. The popularity of cultural tourist spots such as the Tate Modern and Natural History Museum also contributed to these increased visitor numbers.

granite3.1-dense:2b: In 2004, London's National Gallery, a premier destination for UK art lovers housing masterpieces like Raphael's Madonna of the Pinks, experienced a significant surge in visitor numbers. Five million people visited the gallery, making it the second most popular tourist attraction in the country, just behind Blackpool Pleasure Beach. This 13.8% rise returned visitor counts to levels seen before the 9/11 attacks. Charles Saumarez Smith, the gallery's director, attributed this growth to factors such as Trafalgar Square pedestrianization and a robust temporary exhibition program featuring El Greco, Russian Landscapes, and Raphael works. The 2004 exhibitions were particularly successful, exceeding expectations. Saumarez Smith expressed confidence in the gallery's potential for continued success in 2005, with upcoming exhibits of Caravaggio, Stubbs, and Rubens on deck. The Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva) reported that European visitors increased by 10%, while North American numbers grew by about 9%. Numbers from the rest of the world also saw a 20% uptick, primarily due to a boom in low-cost flights from Europe.

Director Charles Saumarez Smith attributed the 13.8% increase to the pedestrianisation of Trafalgar Square and strong temporary exhibitions, including El Greco, Russian Landscape, and Raphael. He expressed confidence in maintaining attendance with upcoming exhibitions featuring Caravaggio, Stubbs, and Rubens. The Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva) reported that budget airlines contributed to the rise in European visitors, with overall tourism from Western Europe up 10%, North America up 9%, and the rest of the world up 20%. Other major cultural sites, such as the Tate Modern and the Natural History Museum, also saw visitor increases of over 10%. Some attractions, including Buckingham Palace and Madame Tussauds, did not submit figures for 2004.
